articles.title: BREAKING NEWS Jetstar planes affected by major glitch causing long delays for passengers - what you need to know
articles.author: MATT JONES
articles.summary: A GPS fault on Jetstar's Airbus A320 Neos and A321 Neos aircraft has caused delays for flights to Bali, Fiji and Hobart. The fault follows a NASA warning about solar flares. Solar flares can interfere with GPS signals and interfere with satellite communications.

articles.title: Lake sediment analysis Holocene warming trend, decoding 10,400 years of tropical Australasia's climate
articles.author: Li Yali
articles.summary: There is a steady warming trend of 2°C throughout the Holocene. This warming trend aligns with other land temperature records. The study was published in the journal CATENA and used organic compounds preserved in the sediments of Girraween Lagoon as paleothermometers.

articles.title: The last time the earth was this hot — here's what the ocean did
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: Sea levels will rise by metres, not centimetres, and the time to prepare is now. Johanna Wagstaffe explains what Earth's past reveals about our coastal future and why smart planning today could protect millions in the decades and centuries to come.

articles.title: Hurricane season 2025: New forecast calls for above normal season but questions remain
articles.author: Palm Beach Daily News
articles.summary: NHC prepares for the 2025 hurricane season with new products. Forecasters cite warmer ocean temperatures and weak hurricane season as reasons to be prepared for the future hurricane season. NHC director Michael Brennan talks about the experimental cone of uncertainty and how it is changing for the hurricane season in 2025.

articles.title: All maritime ports asked to hoist Signal-3
articles.author: Bangla News24.com
articles.summary: Chattogram, Cox's Bazar, Mongla, and Payra maritime ports have been advised to hoist local cautionary signal number three due to squally weather expected to affect the North Bay and adjoining coastal areas. All fishing boats and trawlers operating in North Bay are advised to return to the coast and remain there until further notice.

articles.title: Climate change now threatens thousands of species on Earth
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: In the last decade, report after report has warned that the Arctic is heating up faster than ever, cities are scorching, the Amazon is blazing, boreal forests are shrinking and the oceans are simmering because of human-caused climate change. The goal was to shine a spotlight on the growing role of climate change in the global biodiversity crisis.

articles.title: California Map Shows Cities Where Sea Level Rise Is Accelerating
articles.author: Newsweek
articles.summary: Rising sea level threatens California's infrastructure if left unchecked. California's largest coastal cities have reported rises in sea level that could threaten the state's infrastructure, if left unaddressed, which is a concern for California's governor.    .

articles.title: Seasonal fury intensifying erosion of coast in Salcete
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: The monsoon is wreaking havoc along the Salcete coastline, accelerating the erosion of its sandy beaches. The Arabian Sea is chipping away at the beaches due to changes in sea level, seawater temperature, and other ocean dynamics, which are altering the way the ocean interacts with the land.

articles.title: Climate change and crop production in Montana
articles.author: Ravalli Republic
articles.summary: Montana's agriculture sector has always been vulnerable to changes in climate, but generations of farmers and ranchers have proven their ability to adjust and prosper as conditions demand.    .      in Montana, the climate is changing and Montana's agriculture is vulnerable.

articles.title: Stormy Skies Ahead: NOAA's Resilience Amid Budget Cuts
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: U.S. government agencies predict that the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season will bring above-normal activity, with three to five major hurricanes expected. The National Weather Service forecasts 13 to 19 named tropical storms, with warmer sea surface temperatures cited as a key contributor. NOAA's director, Ken Graham, insists that operational efficiency won't be compromised, despite the Trump administration's cuts impacting over 7% of NOAA's workforce.

articles.title: Michael Haworth: Dangerous days
articles.author: Letters To The Editor
articles.summary: NASA reports rising ocean waters due to thermal expansion, rather than melting glaciers. Earth's people are either complacent, too money hungry, too power hungry, or stupid to act accordingly. The current administration will ensure nothing meaningful will be done until 2029 at the earliest, so Earth will eventually become an uninhabitable planet.

articles.title: Michael Haworth: Dangerous days
articles.author: Letters to the editor
articles.summary: NASA reports rising ocean waters due to thermal expansion, rather than melting glaciers. Earth's people are either complacent, too money hungry, too power hungry, or stupid to act accordingly. The current administration will ensure nothing meaningful will be done until 2029 at the earliest, so Earth will eventually become an uninhabitable planet.

articles.title: Australia's foreign minister wraps up Pacific tour
articles.author: Evan Wasuka
articles.summary: Penny Wong has been on a three-nation Pacific tour visiting Fiji, Tonga, and Vanuatu. She has re-emphasised Australia's commitment to climate action in Fiji and funding health reform in Tonga. Dr Tess Newton Cain expects Assistant Minister Matt Thistlethwaite to take up a more prominent role representing Australia in the region.

articles.title: NOAA PREDICTS ACTIVE HURRICANE SEASON AMID AGENCY CUTS (3pmET)
articles.summary: NOAA is releasing its 2025 Atlantic Hurricane Season forecast amid a flurry of cuts to federal climate and weather research. Experts say the cuts could put property, lives, and the US economy at risk. Michael Yoshida reports for CNN. iReport.com.

articles.title: Climate change increasing extreme heat risk for pregnant women
articles.summary: Climate change is fuelling a sharp rise in extreme heat risk for pregnant women worldwide. Panaji experienced the most additional pregnancy heat-risk days each year (39) on average during the past five years. Sikkim reported the highest number of days with 32 days, while Goa and Kerala recorded 24 and 18 additional days.

articles.title: Spain confirms hottest 3-yr period on record
articles.author: P Aulgiblin Hu Jiaqi
articles.summary: 2022-2024 is the hottest three-year period ever recorded in Spain. It featured three major heatwaves, 31 new high-temperature records and longer, more intense hot spells. Sea temperatures rose for the second consecutive year, contributing to extreme weather events.

articles.title: Climate change and crop production in Montana
articles.author: BRUCE MAXWELL
articles.summary: Montana's agriculture sector has always been vulnerable to changes in climate. Rising temperatures and increasing spring and fall precipitation have benefitted some crop production, but these climate trends pose challenges for Montana's farmers and ranchers. The current climate changes driven by rising greenhouse gas emissions, produced by burning fossil fuels, impact working lands.

articles.title: California Map Shows Cities Where Sea Level Rise Is Accelerating
articles.author: Theo Burman
articles.summary: New data from the Virginia Institute of Marine Science shows that California's largest coastal cities, Los Angeles and San Francisco, have reported rises in sea level that could threaten the state's infrastructure if left unchecked. California has one of the most comprehensive sea level responses in the U.S., with many parts of the coast protected by sea walls.

articles.title: Monsoon likely to arrive early in Pakistan
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Northern and Eastern Punjab are expected to get the most rain, possibly up to 50% more than usual. Punjab's average rainfall could increase from 344 mm to 388 mm. Khyber Pakhtunkhwa's rainfall could go up from 243 mm to 300 mm. Azad Kashmir is also likely to receive heavy rain, while Balochistan is expected to face low rainfall and extreme heat.

articles.title: Is your name on the storm list for the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season? Take a look
articles.author: Michelle Marchante
articles.summary: The 2025 Atlantic hurricane season officially starts on June 1 and runs through Nov. 30. The first storm of the season will be Andrea. There may be a Hurricane Karen or a Tropical Storm Lorenzo in the future.   Â. Â

articles.title: Minnesota flipping from cool and wet to warm and dry
articles.author: Meteorologist Sven Sundgaard
articles.summary: Sven Sundgaard has the latest on the rainfall totals and the warmer than normal air that is slowly moving in now that the rain has departed. A little cooler than normal but mostly dry, most of the time this weekend. 80s return later next week along with drier pattern.

articles.title: Trump's Federal Cuts Threaten Natural Disaster Support Americans Rely On
articles.author: Patricia Mazzei
articles.summary: States and cities along the Atlantic and Gulf coasts are bracing for the likelihood that there will be fewer meteorologists at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration due to significant budget cuts at the federal agencies.    "There is an extraordinary level of uncertainty about the impact of the budget cuts on weather forecasts and emergency response"

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'When Climate Activists Make Things Worse',
articles.author: Stephen Heins
articles.summary: When Climate Activists Make Things Worse, they undermine their own goals. They oppose carbon markets and reject carbon capture and storage. They are against developing local gas fields like Narrabri in NSW, but they are comfortable with LNG import terminals such as Port Kembla. This doesn't reduce global emissions, it shifts them offshore.

articles.title: Maryland's Chesapeake Bay sees concerning drop in blue crab population
articles.author: Christian
articles.summary: Maryland's Chesapeake Bay is seeing a drop in its population of blue crabs. The total crab abundance is 238 million, the lowest count since surveys began in 1990. The decline affected all population segments: adult male crabs to 26 million, adult female crabs to 108 million and juvenile crabs to 103 million.

articles.title: Heat in the Hills: How Kashmir's Climate Is Slowly Turning
articles.author: Contributor
articles.summary: Srinagar, Qazigund, Kokernag, and Pahalgam experienced record-breaking heatwaves in May 2025. Srinagar reached 34.4°C, the highest temperature for the month in years. There was a sharp rise in cases of dehydration and heatstroke, mostly among children and the elderly. The construction of roads, railways, power lines, and housing colonies are eating into forests and wetlands. Black carbon is speeding up warming in the region and setting off a dangerous loop. Glaciers feeding rivers have shrunk by more than 15%.

articles.title: HEADLINE: 'More truth about global warming', by I & I Editorial Board
articles.author: I Editorial Board
articles.summary: Study Shows Urban Heat Skewed U.S. Warming Data For Over A Century. Heartland Institute published a paper written by meteorologist Anthony Watts, which demonstrated that the ground-based system for measuring surface temperatures is unreliable. According to the report, approximately 96% of the temperature stations fail to meet what the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration considers to be 'acceptable'

articles.title: Unusual stretch of May weather has Torontonians fed up
articles.summary: Environment Canada senior climatologist Dave Phillips shares his thoughts on the unseasonably cold weather in Toronto and when Torontonians can expect warmer weather in the coming days. He says it's been unseasonable cold in Toronto recently.

articles.title: Deadly floods ongoing as threatening rain moves south
articles.author: Jack Gramenz
articles.summary: There is an increase in both the intensity and frequency of extreme weather events. Dr Sedighkia says there is an urgent need to reassess how we understand and manage flood risks.    Dr Sedghkia is a professor at the University of Melbourne.

articles.title: Pakistan's climate challenge
articles.author: Mahnoor Raza
articles.summary: Climate change is affecting Pakistan. Pakistan joined the Paris Agreement and the UN climate talks. The government started programmes like the 'Ten Billion Tree Tsunami' and is working to use more clean energy through the Alternative and Renewable Energy Policy. Pakistan needs to take strong actions to fight climate change.

articles.title: A surprising source of clouds in Antarctica: Penguin poop
articles.author: Washington Post
articles.summary: Penguin poop is creating clouds in Antarctica that could be affecting local temperatures, according to new research published Thursday in Communications Earth & Environment. Previous computer models have found such seabird guano-fueled clouds in the Arctic cool the ground, but observations are needed to confirm the effect on the climate.

articles.title: Heat Stress Triggers HSP70 in Klang Valley Populations
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Heat Shock Proteins (HSPs) play a critical role in cellular defense and adaptation to thermal stress. New research conducted in Malaysia's Klang Valley provides insights into the interplay between heat exposure, biological defense and environmental vulnerability. Urban populations with limited access to cooling infrastructure, compounded by occupational heat exposure and crowded living conditions exhibited amplified HSP70 induction. Rural inhabitants, though exposed to physical labor under high temperatures, might benefit from lifestyle adaptations.

articles.title: 3D Model Shows The Catastrophic Consequences Of The Earth's Last Pole Flip, And How Our Ancestors Adapted To Survive
articles.author: Kyra Piperides
articles.summary: The Earth's poles have moved 180 times in its history. The most recent time was Laschamps excursion, 41,000 years ago. This event caused the Earth's magnetic field to reduce and the poles to wander closer to the equator. The result was increased solar radiation. Modern humans learned to adapt to their new circumstances.

articles.title: Gaza's main hospital is overwhelmed with children in pain from malnutrition
articles.author: Associated Press
articles.summary: Experts warn the territory could plunge into famine, as they also warn it could be affected by climate change.    i.e. there could be a shortage of food supplies in the territory.  in the future.  In the past, there have been famines in the region.

articles.title: Forest Loss Around the World Hit Record in 2024
articles.author: Hiroko Tabuchi
articles.summary: The planet lost a record amount of forests last year, mainly because of fires that raged around the world. The loss of pristine rainforests alone was the most significant loss.       in the world last year. In the past year, the world has lost more forest land than ever before.

articles.title: Global Forest Loss Hit a Record Last Year as Fires Raged
articles.summary: The world lost the equivalent of 18 soccer fields of forested land every minute last year. For the first time since record-keeping began, fires were the leading cause of rainforest loss, accounting for nearly half of all destruction. The fires emitted 4.1 gigatons of planet-warming greenhouse gasses.

articles.title: Penguin Poop May Help Preserve Antarctic Climate
articles.author: Bob Berwyn
articles.summary: Penguin guano in Antarctica is an important source of ammonia aerosol particles that help drive the formation and persistence of low clouds. Low clouds cool the climate by reflecting some incoming sunlight back to space. Recent study suggested that the increase in the annual global temperature during 2023 and 2024 was caused in part by a reduction of cloud cover.

articles.title: Global Forest Loss Hit a Record Last Year as Fires Raged
articles.author: Hiroko Tabuchi
articles.summary: The planet lost a record amount of forests last year, mainly because of fires. The world lost the equivalent of 18 soccer fields of forested land every minute. For the first time since record-keeping began, fires were the leading cause of rainforest loss, accounting for nearly half of all destruction.

articles.title: CCAA: Mindanao in humanitarian crisis
articles.author: Franco Jose C. Baroña
articles.summary: Flooding in Mindanao is deepening humanitarian crisis. 192,000 people have been affected across Maguindanao del Sur and neighboring provinces, with floodwaters spreading to Zamboanga del Sur. The worst-impacted towns are Datu Abdullah Sangki, Shariff Aguak, and Mamasapano, home to multiple armed groups and decades-old clan rivalries. Flooding has created alarming security gaps as flooded marshlands serve as illegal transit routes.

articles.title: 5/23 Letters to the editor
articles.summary: The global average temperature in 2024 will be the highest in the past 100,000 years. Sea surface temperatures in the Atlantic and Gulf are rising rapidly and we now know that hot seas spawn bad storms, according to a recent editorial in the journal of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

articles.title: Srinagar swelters as city records third highest May temperature in 133 years
articles.author: Zulfikar Majid
articles.summary: It's the hottest day of the season so far in the summer capital of Jammu and Kashmir. Today's maximum temperature was 9°C above normal, according to the local MeT office. The mercury soared to 34.4°C, surpassing previous records.

articles.title: Kanlaon eruption causes P1.8 million damage to crops
articles.author: Gilbert Bayoran
articles.summary: Kanlaon Volcano had a minor eruption on May 13. It destroyed P1.8 million worth of agricultural crops in Negros Occidental. In June and December last year, the Kanlaon eruptions caused P129 million in damage to agriculture.

articles.title: NC beekeepers work to save honeybees after Helene
articles.author: WRAL
articles.summary: Todd Swanson is the leader of the Ashe County Beekeepers Association in western North Carolina. He talks about efforts to save honeybees after Hurricane Helene's devastation and the efforts of the association to save the bees.      Â   .

articles.title: FAO introduces innovative tools to improve Caribbean fisheries management
articles.author: Now Grenada
articles.summary: The Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations (FAO) held a webinar on 12 May 2025 on the use of Geographic Information System (GIS) mapping, remote sensing by satellites and Artificial Intelligence (AI) to improve the sustainability of the fisheries sector in the Caribbean. There were 29 participants from Dominica, Grenada, St Kitts and Nevis, St Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago who attended the webinar.

articles.title: Busy hurricane season expected as forecasters fear Trump cuts
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: Mark Poynting is a climate reporter for BBC News. He reports on climate news from London. He is based at the BBC News website.       .  Â   in the article attribution is the author's responsibility.

articles.title: Media advisory - Environment and Climate Change Canada presents the 2025 hurricane season outlook
articles.author: CNW Group
articles.summary: Bob Robichaud, Warning Preparedness Meteorologist with Environment and Climate Change Canada's Canadian Hurricane Centre, will present the outlook for the upcoming hurricane season on Friday, May 23, 2025 at 10:00 a.m. (Atlantic Time) via Zoom. Media representatives interested in asking a question should change their screen names to include their full name and media outlet.

articles.title: Media advisory - Environment and Climate Change Canada presents the 2025 hurricane season outlook Français
articles.author: Environment
articles.summary: Bob Robichaud, Warning Preparedness Meteorologist with Environment and Climate Change Canada's (ECCC) Canadian Hurricane Centre, will present the outlook for the upcoming hurricane season on Friday, May 23, 2025 at 10:00 a.m. (Atlantic Time) via Zoom. Following the briefing, media will have the opportunity to ask questions.

articles.title: The surprising climate power of penguin poo
articles.author: France 24
articles.summary: Ammonia from penguin guano seeds extra cloud cover above coastal Antarctica, blocking sunlight and nudging temperatures down. The research was published Thursday in Communications Earth & Environment. The penguin population is declining, which could have a positive climate-warming feedback.

articles.title: The surprising climate power of penguin poo
articles.author: Issam Ahmed
articles.summary: Antarctica is warming due to human-driven climate change. Ammonia wafting from penguin guano seeds extra cloud cover above coastal Antarctica, which blocks sunlight and cools the area.      Â   .

articles.title: How penguin poop can help to mitigate climate change
articles.author: JULIA JACOBO
articles.summary: Ammonia in penguin poop could help to reduce the impacts of climate change by contributing to increased cloud formation, according to a paper published in Communications Earth & Environment on Thursday. The researchers spent two months from January to March 2023 measuring the concentration of ammonia in the air near a colony of 60,000 Adelie penguins at Marambio Base in Antarctica.

articles.title: How pungent poop could help Antarctica's penguins
articles.author: Laura Baisas
articles.summary: There is a lot of activity going on the internet. There is a discussion on the topic of the weather. There are many people talking about it. The discussion is about the weather, the climate, and the people who are discussing it on the Internet. There's a discussion about the current weather.

articles.title: This tiny Australian bat is the size of a matchbox. But it flies up to 150km a night in search of food
articles.author: Petra Stock
articles.summary: Southern bent-wing bats roost in caves in south-west Victoria and south-east South Australia. Victoria's Arthur Rylah Institute tracked bats from the Portland maternity cave 350km west of Melbourne. Some bats flew from Portland to the Naracoorte maternity caves in South Australia or to Victoria's Warrnambool maternity caves – about 156km and 97km away in a single night. The bats mostly returned on subsequent nights via a second direct, single-night flight. The average person commutes 16km to work in Australia. There are fewer than 45,000 of the endangered species.

articles.title: A surprising source of clouds in Antarctica: Penguin poop
articles.author: Kasha Patel
articles.summary: Penguin guano is fueling clouds in Antarctica. The clouds may have varying cooling or warming effects depending on whether they're located over ocean or ice. Previous computer models have found such seabird guano-fueled clouds in the Arctic do cool the ground, but observations are needed to confirm the effect on the climate.

articles.title: Penguin droppings ‘delaying' climate change
articles.author: Joe Pinkstone
articles.summary: Ammonia from penguin excrement helps form clouds that deflect sunlight and lower temperatures. Research station near Marambio Base in Antarctica was close to a colony of 60,000 Adélie penguins in early 2023. The guano gas reacts with sulphur in the atmosphere to produce aerosols which attract water vapour to form fog and clouds.

articles.title: Top 5 health concerns amid changing UK weather patterns
articles.author: Gayathri Kallukaran
articles.summary: The UK is seeing more unpredictable weather due to climate change. There are health risks associated with heatwaves, dengue, chikungunya, zika, and Lyme disease, flooding, and air pollution. Climate change is disrupting food production and water availability in the UK.

articles.title: 'Unprecedented' marine heatwave hits waters around Devon, Cornwall and Ireland
articles.author: Sandra Laville
articles.summary: The sea off the south coast of Devon, Cornwall and west coast of Ireland is experiencing an unprecedented marine heatwave. The usual springtime water temperatures would be 11C-12C, but the waters are now at absolute temperatures of 15C-16C. The UK is increasingly being hit by marine heatwaves.

articles.title: Fisheries in Dominica and other islands work with FAO to explore advanced industry tech tools
articles.author: Malaika
articles.summary: The Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations hosted a webinar on May 12, 2025. The event brought together 29 participants from fisheries agencies from Dominica, Grenada, St. Kitts and Nevis, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, and Trinidad and Tobago. The discussion focused on how to improve the sustainability of fisheries in the Caribbean.

articles.title: Survey finds Wisconsin farmers value sustainable practices
articles.summary: A recent survey of Wisconsin's farmers found that 56 percent of them believe climate change is happening. Another 26 percent think it isn't happening, and 18 percent are unsure. Those statistics might seem startling for a group who work outdoors every day and are attuned to the cadences of nature.

articles.title: Drought fears increase as NRW change status for Wales
articles.summary: Dry start to the year is causing concern for the health of ecosystems and habitats and for land management and the agricultural sector. The whole of Wales has been placed into prolonged dry weather status.       .   in the whole of the country.

articles.title: Indonesia lost less forest in 2024, with caveat
articles.author: Gembong Hanung
articles.summary: Indonesia recorded a decline in deforestation last year compared with the figure in 2023. More than 6.7 million hectares of tropical primary forests were lost last year, mainly due to human-induced forest and land fires. Experts warn the government not to be complacent and urged Prabowo Subianto to work harder to cut deforestation.

articles.title: Africa could face 113 million climate migrants by 2050, warn researchers
articles.author: The Nation
articles.summary: Africa is at risk of experiencing a massive human migration crisis due to climate change. Over 113 million people could become climate migrants by 2050 due to the escalating impacts, according to the researchers. The Nation Newspaper reports that researchers warn that Africa could face 113 million climate migrants.

articles.title: ‘Unprecedented' marine heatwave hits waters around Devon, Cornwall and Ireland
articles.author: Sandra Laville
articles.summary: Temperatures in the sea off the south coast of Devon, Cornwall and Ireland have risen by between 2C and 4C above average for this time of the year. The marine heatwave began in March and has lasted for almost two months. There are fears of mass die-offs of fish and other marine life if the heatwave continues.

articles.title: Srinagar records 3rd highest-ever May Day temperature in 133 years, seethes at 34.4 degree Celsius
articles.author: GK Web Desk
articles.summary: Srinagar recorded 34.4 degree Celsius on May Day. The previous record was 34.3 degree Celsius recorded on May 28, 1971. It's the third highest-ever May Day temperature in 133 years, according to Faizan Arif.

articles.title: More Truth About Global Warming
articles.author: Issues
articles.summary: A recent study might embolden climate alarmists to organize forced marches into rural areas, according to the author of a recent study. The author hopes the study will calm the alarmists, but it might instead embolden them to organize such a march in the future.

articles.title: Relief ops underway in flood-stricken areas in Maguindanao
articles.author: Gma Regional Tv News
articles.summary: The Bangsamoro government beefed up emergency response operations in areas affected by the recent massive flooding in Maguindanao del Norte and Maguinano del Sur. Up to 138 barangays in 14 towns were affected by flooding following continuous rains triggered by the Intertropical Convergence Zone (ITCZ). Hundreds of residents were displaced and more than 2,033 hectares of crops and livestock were destroyed. Two wooden bridges in Barangay Bagumbong, Mamasapano were damaged and some schools in Datu Piang experienced flooding. DatuPiang has been placed under a state of calamity on May 21, 2025.

articles.title: A deadly mosquito-borne illness rises as the US cuts all climate and health funding
articles.author: Zoya Teirstein
articles.summary: Climate change is driving an explosion in dengue cases in the U.S., which will make studying the connection between climate change and the disease more difficult.    Grist, Seattle, Washington.  Grit, Seattle.  grist.com.

articles.title: Suffolk coast experiencing record high marine heatwave
articles.author: Thomas Marks
articles.summary: Suffolk has been experiencing a record-breaking marine heatwave. The sea surface temperature of the sea along the Suffolk coast is between 1C and 2C above the average. The rising temperatures can affect the plankton blooms, which are the base of the marine food chain, as well as the possibility of harmful algal blooms.

articles.title: ‘Global red alert': Wildfires drive record forest loss in 2024, alarming data reveals
articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Global forest loss surged to record levels in 2024, with wildfires destroying 6.7 million hectares of tropical primary forest. For the first time, fires, not agriculture, were the leading driver of tropical forest loss, according to data released by Global Forest Watch. The report attributes the shift to human activity, rising land pressure and extreme heat, worsened by El Niño and the climate crisis.

articles.title: BLOG: Adopt Climate Smart Agriculture To Enhance Productivity and Environmental Protection in Isingiro District
articles.author: Chimp Reports
articles.summary: Isingiro district in Western Uganda has been suffering from drought for several years. The prolonged droughts have led to food shortages and famine-like conditions. This has threatened the livelihoods of farmers and the district's position as a food producer. Uganda's government is working on a project called Climate-Smart Irrigation Project in the drought-prone district called Isingiro.

articles.title: Climate Threat to Africa's Food Exports May Empty EU Shelves
articles.summary: Climate change and biodiversity loss are crippling agricultural production in Africa. Africa is a key exporter of staples such as cocoa, coffee, and maize. Half of EU food imports come from countries that lack the resources to adapt to climate change. EU is the world's biggest consumer, producer, and explier of chocolate. Most of its cocoa imports are from Cote d'Ivoire, Ghana, Cameroon and Nigeria in West Africa, and Ecuador in South America.

articles.title: Do We Need a Global Climate Lockdown?
articles.author: Atta Ur Rehman
articles.summary: There is a global climate lockdown on the agenda. People are debating whether or not the world needs such a lockdown to save the planet. The debate stirs up anxiety, hope and fierce arguments everywhere. Let's break it all down, warts and all, and see what's really at stake.

articles.title: Wildfires drive record global forest losses
articles.author: Tom Chivers
articles.summary: In tropical regions, fire is the biggest cause of forest loss for the first time since records began, ahead of logging, agriculture, and mining. Brazil saw the greatest losses — 10,000 square miles, or 42% of the total area lost. 17 of the 20 most forested countries saw greater losses than in 2021 when a global deal to protect woodland was signed.

articles.title: Greece beefs up firefighting prowess for blazing summer
articles.author: Derek Gatopoulos
articles.summary: Greece is deploying a record number of firefighters and nearly doubling its drone fleet this summer to address growing wildfire risks driven by climate change, to combat the problem.      Â   i   in Greece is deploying more firefighters and drones to fight wildfires.

articles.title: Greece beefs up firefighting prowess for blazing summer
articles.author: Derek Gatopoulos
articles.summary: Greece is deploying a record number of firefighters and nearly doubling its drone fleet this summer to address growing wildfire risks driven by climate change, to combat the problem.      Â   i   in Greece is deploying more firefighters and drones to fight wildfires.

articles.title: Other views: Trump destroying programs that help prepare for natural disasters
articles.author: Tim Trainor
articles.summary: Donald Trump's administration is on a crusade against efforts to grapple with climate change. The administration has been cutting federal programs that protect Americans against extreme weather. The decisions will weaken the economy and could cost lives. Lawmakers need to speak up for their constituents and press for mitigation and adaptation measures.

articles.title: Greece's Fierce Battle Against Wildfires Amid Climate Change
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The government is boosting firefighter numbers to 18,000 and investing heavily in new equipment to avoid a repeat of last year's alarming fire season, which saw nearly 10,000 wildfires in Greece. The exercise involving firefighters, rescuers and the military took place in Lavrio, south of Athens.

articles.title: Suffolk coast experiencing record marine heatwave
articles.author: Thomas Marks
articles.summary: Coastal waters across the UK are experiencing a record-breaking marine heatwave. The Suffolk coast is also seeing highs. The rising temperatures can affect the plankton blooms, the base of the marine food chain and the marine ecosystems. It can also affect the growth and reproduction of species and fisheries.

articles.title: Warming of the earth!
articles.summary: The eight years between 2015 and 2022 were the hottest on record. 850 million people lived in regions that experienced all-time high temperatures. One study found that a heat wave like the one that cooked the Pacific Northwest in 2021 is 150 times more likely today than it was before we began the atmosphere with CO2.

articles.title: Kenya Launches New Initiative to Strengthen Climate Disaster Response
articles.author: Ecofin Agency
articles.summary: Kenya has launched the "Early Warnings for All" initiative to strengthen national and community resilience against climate-related disasters. 5% of Kenya's 2025 disaster risk management budget has been allocated to upgrading early warning infrastructure. Flooding between March and May 2024 affected 410,000 people and caused 315 deaths. UN Office for Disaster Risk Reduction estimates total economic losses at $1.4 billion.

articles.title: Greece deploys record firefighters and more drones for wildfire season
articles.summary: Greece is deploying a record number of firefighters and nearly doubling its drone fleet this summer to address growing wildfire risks driven by climate change. Civil Protection Minister Ioannis Kefalogiannis says 18,000 permanent and seasonal personnel, supported by thousands of volunteers, will be mobilized.

articles.title: Greece doubles drone fleet and deploys record firefighters to tackle growing wildfire risk
articles.author: Derek Gatopoulos
articles.summary: Greece is deploying a record number of firefighters and nearly doubling its drone fleet this summer to address growing wildfire risks driven by climate change. Civil Protection Minister Ioannis Kefalogiannis says 18,000 permanent and seasonal personnel, supported by thousands of volunteers, will be mobilized.

articles.title: Greece doubles drone fleet and deploys record firefighters to tackle growing wildfire risk
articles.author: DEREK GATOPOULOS
articles.summary: Greece is deploying a record number of firefighters and nearly doubling its drone fleet this summer to address growing wildfire risks driven by climate change, officials said Thursday.  Copyright 2025 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast or rewritten without permission.

articles.title: Havana sets new May temperature record at 38°C (100.4°F)
articles.author: Reet Kaur
articles.summary: On May 18, the Veguitas station in Granma province recorded 37.1 °C (98.8 °F) in Havana. Most Cuban regions reported temperatures between 32 °C and 35 °C during early May. The recent heatwave is influenced by a well-structured anticyclone affecting all layers of the troposphere.

articles.title: Caribbean faces increasing climate threats
articles.author: Curlan Campbell
articles.summary: 2025 Wet and Hurricane Season Caribbean Climate Outlook Forum scheduled for 22 May in Grenada. Main concerns include extreme heat, Saharan dust, unpredictable behaviour of tropical cyclones, and changing weather patterns. 2023 and 2024 were the hottest years on record globally.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning over troubling new threat facing historic US landmark: 'Something we should be worried about'
articles.author: Matthew Swigonski
articles.summary: The Pacific Ocean could rise by around 7 feet by 2100, according to a report by the California Legislature's Nonpartisan Fiscal and Policy Advisor. Alcatraz's shoreline is susceptible to increased erosion and flooding, which could impact buildings and ecosystems. Scientists and conservationists are working to monitor and mitigate these effects through 3D mapping and other strategies.

articles.title: Fires drive ‘record loss' of world's forests
articles.author: TTE
articles.summary: Fires drive 'record loss' of world's forests. Last year was the hottest on record. The burning forests released more than four times the greenhouse gas emissions of all air travel in 2023. Global leaders will meet in Belem, Brazil, for Cop climate talks in the Amazon rainforest.

articles.title: Rural nonprofit boosts fight against gender-based violence and femicide scourge in Eastern Cape
articles.author: Naledi Sikhakhane
articles.summary: Border Rural Committee is a rural development NGO working in the central and eastern parts of the Eastern Cape. It focuses on food security projects aimed at women in rural areas. GBV is a problem in rural Eastern Cape, especially in rural communities with limited resources and opportunities. The project provides support through inputs and training for small-scale farmers for their consumption and selling.

articles.title: Peterborough's May 22 forecast: Periods of rain
articles.author: Torstar Open Data Team
articles.summary: This story was automatically generated using data from Environment and Climate Change Canada. It is sponsored by The Peterborough Examiner. It has been updated to reflect the fact that the author has moved to Peterborough, not the city. It does not have a false flag flag.

articles.title: Why growing Arctic wetlands are actually bad for Earth
articles.author: Michael Booth
articles.summary: Global warming is expanding Arctic wetlands that naturally pump out more methane. Biologic material naturally breaking down in swampy areas produces methane, which is a super-accelerant with 30 times greater impact on warming over 100 years than equal amounts of carbon dioxide. The research team has seen sharp increases in methane from biologic causes like wetlands and garbage breakdown in landfills since 2007.

articles.title: Record Dutch drought threatens wildlife as light rain offers no relief
articles.summary: The Netherlands is in the midst of its driest spring since recordkeeping began. Bird conservation groups are warning of serious consequences for nature. The extreme drought is drying out wetlands and meadows, leaving tens of thousands of birds struggling to find food and build nests. On Thursday, early rain fell mainly across the northern provinces, while light showers passed over parts of the south. The rest of the day will bring a mix of clouds and sunshine, with brief showers expected in the north and northeast. The southern provinces, including Noord-Brabant and Limburg should stay mostly dry until the overnight. On Sunday, the rain will move eastward into Germany.

articles.title: Government launches early warning plan to combat disasters
articles.author: Lilys Njeru
articles.summary: The government has launched an initiative aimed at protecting lives and livelihoods during disasters. The 'Early Warnings for All' initiative in Kenya will ensure that everyone is protected by life-saving early warning systems by 2027. The initiative is anchored on four pillars, including data collection, risk assessment, observation and forecasting, dissemination and communication.

articles.title: Brisbane rising on global rankings, but still behind southern capitals
articles.author: Sean Parnell
articles.summary: Brisbane has risen four places on a global cities ranking, breaking into the top 25, but still ranks below Melbourne and Sydney. Oxford Economics finds the older cities' work and economic performance justifies their place in the overall top 10. According to the latest Global Cities Index, Brisbane outperforms Melbourne on the environment and is equal with other Australian cities on governance.

articles.title: Why two Pittsburgh reporters went to Australia
articles.author: Rich Lord
articles.summary: 'Alcoa mines Australia's forest' was published in PublicSource this week. The nonprofit newsroom sent a team to Western Australia for 16 days to bring home a story of an American company's collision with a unique and imperiled ecosystem. PublicSource applied for the Pulitzer Center's Richard C. Longworth Media Fellowship, which aims to reconnect Midwestern readers with international stories that impact their lives.

articles.title: Somalia Climate Shocks And Aid Cuts Create Perfect Storm
articles.author: ETV Bharat
articles.summary: Mohamed Abdukadir Teesto's house in Mogadishu was destroyed by flooding this month. He is among 24,000 people affected by the flooding in the Banadir region. The UN says its humanitarian needs for the year -- estimated at $1.4 billion -- are only 12 per cent funded so far. This month, CARE International said Somalia had 1.8 million severely malnourished children under five.

articles.title: A new metric for measuring greenhouse gases
articles.author: Robert Hicks
articles.summary: As we fuel our daily lives, we're fuelling a growing concern — climate change. Every litre of fuel we burn produces 2.345 kilograms of carbon dioxide. This is a mass of invisible greenhouse gas equivalent to the volume of a 109-centimetre cube that will linger in the atmosphere for hundreds of years.

articles.title: West Africa: Chocolate and Rice Among Key EU Imports Facing Climate Threats
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: Climate change and biodiversity loss threaten food production in countries that export to the EU, a report warns. European supermarket shelves could become emptier due to climate change and loss of biodiversity, according to the report published on Wednesday. The report was published by the World Resources Institute.

articles.title: Hurricanes, an annual threat
articles.author: Newsday
articles.summary: The rainy season transitions into the hurricane season in two weeks. Last year's hurricane devastated the Grenadines. There is an urgent need for enhanced preparedness and resilience strategies in Trinidad and Tobago. Public awareness campaigns are vital to educate residents about safety protocols, evacuation plans, and the importance of securing property.

articles.title: Rain Showers Bring Silver Lining to Summer Crop Outlook
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The timely rainfall following intense heat conditions has not adversely affected major crops. However, hailstorms in Uttar Pradesh and Bihar might have caused mango and litchi fruits to fall prematurely. Paddy sowing preparations for the upcoming season are advancing smoothly. Foodgrain production estimates are likely to see an upward revision.

articles.title: Australia's knowledge of Russia is dwindling. We need to start training our future experts now
articles.summary: Russia's interest in basing long-range aircraft at an Indonesian airbase not far from Australian shores surprised many in Australia. Indonesia's non-aligned stance makes granting such a request unlikely, but Russia's defence and political ties with Southeast Asia have been deepening over the last decade. Russia is a nuclear weapons state with more than 5,500 nuclear warheads and a permanent member of the UN Security Council.

articles.title: Severe heatwave alert in Punjab: CM Maryam Nawaz issues precautionary directives
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: A severe heatwave is expected to hit various parts of Punjab starting today. Lahore, Faisalabad, and Sargodha may be affected. Chief Minister Maryam Nawaz Sharif has issued an alert to both the public and district administrations. Children, the elderly, and the sick should avoid going outdoors unnecessarily. Farm owners have been instructed to ensure shaded areas and an adequate water supply for livestock. Outdoor activities in public and private institutions have been suspended. School administrations have been directed to ensure that at least one fan is functional in each classroom.

articles.title: Ukraine's War Tactics Evolve Weekly—Why Isn't Australia Keeping Up? General Asks
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: The Ukraine-Russia War has revolutionised battlefield tactics, but Australia is slow on the uptake. Retired major general believes the learning and adaptation cycle may be the most transformative development to emerge from the war, and Australia needs to be on the forefront of it.

articles.title: Supreme Court Demands Action on Heatwave Crisis Amidst Rising Threats
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The Supreme Court has called upon the Centre to respond to a Public Interest Litigation (PIL) emphasizing the urgent need to tackle heatwave conditions following over 700 related deaths last year. Chief Justice B R Gavai and Justice Augustine George Masih issued notices to various ministries and the National Disaster Management Authority, requiring their responses within two weeks.

articles.title: Liawenee v Marble Bar: Australia's wildest-weather towns go head to head
articles.author: Amy Cooper
articles.summary: Marble Bar is Australia's hottest town. It sweltered through 160 consecutive days above 100 degrees Fahrenheit between October 1923 and April 1924. In January 2024, it had 26 days above 43 degrees. In August 2014, it set a new August record of 39.7 degrees.

articles.title: Liawenee v Marble Bar: Australia's wildest-weather towns go head to head
articles.author: Amy Cooper
articles.summary: Amy is from Scotland and she came to Australia to escape the cold. It was very hot in Marble Bar, WA. It sweltered through 160 consecutive days above 100 degrees between October 1923 and April 1924. In Liawanee it was -14.2 degrees. Tasmania is the coldest place in the state with an average temperature of -65 degrees.

articles.summary: A low-pressure area has formed over East-Central Arabian Sea about 1075 km southeast of Karachi. The system is likely to intensify into a Depression during next 36 hours and move towards north. There is no threat to any coastal area of the country. If the system turns into a cyclone, it will be named Shakti.

articles.title: Chef Zach Green slams ignorant racist comments
articles.author: Dianne Bortoletto
articles.summary: Zach Green, 35, is a professional cook and a descendant of the Gundjimara people in south west Victoria and Palawa people in Tasmania. He has been living in Port Hedland for 17 years and is married. Mr Green is an ambassador for 'The Burnt Chef Project, a community not-for-profit project designed to remove the stigma surrounding mental health in the hospitality trade. He will cook at Pilbara Pride on 15 June and at Hearson's Cove near Karratha on July 12.

articles.summary: Climate change will make Ireland more vulnerable to flooding and sea-level rise. The OPW's approach reflects its outdated mandate under the 1945 Arterial Drainage Act, which requires it to prioritise water-related projects.

articles.summary: Using data from 37 ground-based ionosondes and COSMIC-2 satellites, the researchers constructed one of the most detailed global maps of sporadic E activity during and after the storm. He also advises the public to support the government's climate change adaptation and mitigation actions.

articles.title: 'Red alert': Fires drive tropical forest loss to record high
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: The world lost 67,000 square kilometres (25,900 square miles) of tropical rainforest last year. The loss was 80 percent higher than in 2023. Fires are responsible for nearly half of these losses. For the first time, fires surpassed agriculture as the main driver of destruction.

articles.title: Tropical forest loss doubles, fire a leading cause: Report
articles.summary: Fires caused by dry conditions, in turn brought about by the climate crisis resulted in record forest loss in 2024, including in India. India lost 22,958 hectares of primary forests compared to 21,672 hectares in 2023. For the first time, fires and not agriculture were the leading cause of tropical primary forest loss, accounting for nearly 50% of all forest loss. The Amazon recorded its highest tree cover loss since 2016.

articles.title: Holocene Warming Trend Found in Lake Sediments Study
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Scientists from Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology at the Chinese Academy of Sciences reconstructed mean annual air temperatures over the past 10,400 years. Results revealed a steady warming trend of 2°C throughout the Holocene. El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) activity changed the climate of tropical Australasia from cool and wet to warmer and drier.

They expect seven hurricanes to emerge from the North Atlantic this summer, with at least three becoming major, powerful storms. The relative temperature of the part of the ocean where cyclones and tropical storms form is not as warm as in the past two years.

articles.title: Budget Cuts Funding Promised To Pacific Communities On Frontlines Of Climate Crisis
articles.author: Oxfam Aotearoa
articles.summary: Today's budget has cut $100 million in funding for climate-vulnerable communities in the Pacific by half the amount needed to maintain New Zealand's current level of climate finance. Oxfam Aotearoa and 22 other members of the Council for International Development called for an increase in climate finance in March this year. New Zealand joined with other governments at COP29 to promise to triple funding by 2030.

articles.title: 1 dead, 50,000 stranded in eastern Australia floods
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Torrential rain continues to lash eastern Australia today, swelling already engorged rivers, engulfing roads and leaving almost 50,000 people stranded. Police found the body of a 63-year-old man inside a flooded home in the rural hamlet of Moto, 400km northeast of Sydney. The town of Kempsey, on the banks of the Macleay River, was surrounded with little warning. More than 20,000 were isolated in the local government area alone.

articles.title: Aus cities break into global top 10
articles.author: Sophie Foster
articles.summary: Two Australian capitals have made it into the top 10 of an elite global index. Melbourne is the highest-ranking Australian city. Brisbane is ranked 23rd in the world. Perth is ranked in 31st place. The top 10 cities on the index were New York, London, San Jose, Seattle, Melbourne, Sydney, Boston, Tokyo and San Francisco.

articles.title: PWB Kitties Love Hummingbirds
articles.author: mamajo2k
articles.summary: The kitties gather pictures and write about hummingbirds this week. They are the smallest birds on the planet. Central and South America have the most hummingbird species. They have tiny nests made with spider silk which allows the nest to expand as the chicks grow. The hummers are curious and will fly up to the glass to check out the kittehs.

articles.title: The intensifying climate driver behind the coastal deluges and inland drought
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: From Queensland to the South Coast of NSW, rainfall has been unusually high this week. Taree on the Mid North Coast recorded its highest ever two-day rainfall on record in the two days to 9am Wednesday. Climate change is increasing the amount of moisture the atmosphere can hold by 7 percentage points of humidity for every degree of warming.

articles.title: The intensifying climate driver behind the coastal deluges and inland drought
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons

articles.title: The intensifying climate driver behind the coastal deluges and inland drought
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Even before the devastating floods this week, it has been a sodden few months for most of the east coast of Australia. Just a few hours inland, great swaths of the southern half of the continent are gripped by record-breaking drought. The weather bureau's long-term outlook suggests winter could finally bring drought-busting rain to inland and southern parts of the country.

articles.title: Rossby Waves Drive Preferred Terrestrial Heatwave Paths
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: In the face of intensifying global heatwaves, understanding the mechanisms behind their origins and propagation is crucial. A new study by Wang, Huang, Franzke, and colleagues sheds new light on the dynamic atmospheric processes that dictate how heatwaves unfold across continents. They found that Rossby wave activity is responsible for establishing preferred pathways along which terrestrial heatwaves propagate. This insight marks a paradigm shift, allowing meteorologists to anticipate not just localized heat events but larger-scale, connected heatwave episodes.

articles.title: Population rise on agenda
articles.author: Jeanette Severs
articles.summary: The population growth of Gippsland was the topic of conversation at breakfast at Farm World in late March. It was discussed at the breakfast in which it was mentioned that Gipp'sland has a lot of people.       .

articles.author: Stuti Mishra
articles.summary: Wildfires destroyed 6.7 million hectares of tropical primary forest in 2024, according to new satellite data. For the first time, fires are the leading cause of tropical forest loss. Global Forest Watch has called it a 'global red alert' for forest destruction.

articles.title: UK sea temperatures soar after exceptionally warm Spring

articles.summary: Marine heatwaves last longer in the UK than usual. Oceans absorbed 90% of the excess heat created by humans burning fossil fuels. Sea surface temperatures have been increasing by 0.3C per decade over the last 40 years. Long spell of warm, dry weather is expected to break this weekend.

articles.title: Why more British expats are calling Australia home
articles.author: Times News Group
articles.summary: For generations, Australia has held a certain allure for Britons seeking a change of scenery. Australia is a popular destination for Brits seeking a break from the UK.   for many reasons. For others, it's a source of adventure. for many people.

articles.title: Somalia climate shocks and aid cuts create perfect storm
articles.author: Hassan Ali Elmi
articles.summary: Mohamed Abdukadir Teesto's home in the Somali capital was battered by torrential rains. The Horn of Africa nation is among the most vulnerable to climate change. In the last five years it has experienced both the worst drought in 40 years and once-in-a-century flooding.

articles.title: Summer has gotten hotter nearly everywhere: See where it's worst
articles.author: Stephanie Weaver
articles.summary: Since 1970, 97% of major U.S. cities have seen a 2.6°F rise in average summer temperatures. Nearly one-third of the cities have warmed by 3°F or more since 1970. The top five summer warming cities were: Reno (11.3°F), Boise, Idaho, El Paso, Texas, Las Vegas, 6.1°F, and Salt Lake City, Utah (5.9°F). In 2023, a record 2,325 people died from heat in the United States.

articles.title: Ever wondered what you would do if your town flooded? There's a game for that

articles.summary: Niwa's Future Coasts Aotearoa five-year research project is focused on coastal lowlands. A new game from NIWA uses research into flooding and economics to play out a version of our climate changed future.

articles.title: The earth hath no fury like cyclones disrupted, new studies say

articles.summary: In the SSP5-8.5 scenario, the world's cyclones will be more destructive due to climate change. A follow-up study published by the same team and two more researchers also reported that roughly half of world's mangroves will be at high to severe risk by 2100. Coastal ecosystems protect inland areas from storms, reduce soil erosion and store carbon.

articles.title: Wildfires fuelled record tropical forest loss in 2024

articles.summary: The destruction of the world's tropical forests soared to a record high in 2024. An estimated 6.7 million hectares of tropical primary forest were lost last year. The rise in fire-related deforestation is largely driven by escalating global temperatures. The data reveals a dramatic surge in deforestation.

articles.title: New study documents significant cooling across Eurasia since 2004

articles.title: Amazon fires drive unprecedented global forest loss in 2024
articles.author: Manuela Andreoni
articles.summary: Brazil leads in tropical forest loss due to Amazon fires, Bolivia's forest loss surged by 200 percent in 2024, and Southeast Asia sees decrease in primary forest loss. Global forest loss is on the rise due to climate change, and is expected to smash records in 2024.

articles.author: Hassan Ali Elmi
articles.summary: Mohamed Abdukadir Teesto's home in the Somali capital was battered by torrential rains. The Horn of Africa nation is among the most vulnerable to climate change, according to the UN. In the last five years it has experienced both the worst drought in 40 years and once-in-a-century flooding.

articles.title: Rapid sea ice loss threatens bowhead whales' Arctic habitat: study
articles.author: Source: Xinhua
articles.summary: Sea ice loss could shrink the bowhead whale's summer foraging habitat in the Arctic by up to 75 percent by the end of the century. Sea of Okhotsk, home to one of only four remaining bowhead populations, is projected to lose all viable summer habitat by 2060. By 2100, only a few fragmented habitats will remain.

articles.title: Floods hit Australia's New South Wales
articles.summary: Floods hit Australia's New South Wales. Small plane crashes in San Diego. EU population now 449.3 million. Two Israeli Embassy staff members killed outside Jewish museum in Washington DC. EU decides to lift economic sanctions on Syria. Manhunt continues after New Orleans jail break.

articles.title: A surprising source of clouds over Antarctica: Penguin poo
articles.author: Kasha Patel
articles.summary: Penguin guano is fueling clouds in Antarctica. The clouds may have cooling or warming effects depending on whether they're located over ocean or ice. Previous computer models have found such seabird guano-fueled clouds in the Arctic do cool the ground, but observations are needed to confirm the effect on the climate.

articles.title: Homeowners of Color Face Greater Climate Risk
articles.author: New York Times
articles.summary: Nonwhite communities may have a more difficult road ahead as climate change exacerbates major weather events, as a result of climate change, according to the report. The report is based on the IPCC's assessment of the current global warming trend.    .

articles.title: NOAA predicts plenty of hurricanes in 2025: What to know at a glance
articles.author: Clarionledger
articles.summary: NOAA predicts a 60% chance of an above-average Atlantic hurricane season for 2025. Warm sea surface temperatures are probably the No. 1 contributor to the whole thing, according to Michael Brennan, the director of the National Hurricane Center. He talks about how to prepare for the upcoming hurricane season.

articles.title: Polar blast to strike Australia
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: A polar blast originating in Antarctica is headed towards southeastern Australia. Weatherzone meteorologist Anthony Sharwood warned the cold front is likely to hit on Monday. The system is expected to deliver rain, wild winds and potentially heavy snowfalls to alpine areas. It will freeze millions of Aussies.

articles.title: Over 2,000 migratory birds recorded in Musandam this year
articles.author: Muskat Daily
articles.summary: More than 2,000 migratory birds were recorded in Musandam in the first three months of 2025. The governorate is a stopover on global bird migration routes. EA's specialists documented 2,183 birds between January and March of this year. It is important to raise scientific knowledge in environmental fields.

articles.title: Govt. will develop biodiversity parks in all districts and ‘Pallevanams' in villages, says Andhra Pradesh ...
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: The relationship of human beings with nature has been exploitative, and the impact of deforestation is more profound than ever before, says the author.    -      .   in his book, "Deforestation: The Impact of Deforestation".

articles.title: Media advisory - Environment and Climate Change Canada presents the 2025 hurricane season outlook Français
articles.author: Canada Newswire
articles.summary: Bob Robichaud will present the outlook for the upcoming 2025 hurricane season at the event in Darmouth, NS, on November 25th. He is a Warning Preparedness Meteorologist with Environment and Climate Change Canada's (ECCC) Canadian Hurricane Centre.

articles.title: The surprising climate power of penguin poo
articles.author: The Courier Times
articles.summary: Antarctica is warming due to human-driven climate change. A new study points to penguin poo as an unlikely ally in the fight to keep the continent cool. The study was published in the journal "The International Journal of Climatology".

articles.title: New Zealand's urban gulls adapt to human-altered world: study
articles.author: Xinhua
articles.summary: The Southern black-backed gull, or karoro, has dramatically altered its diet and behavior in response to human-driven environmental changes. Karoro were once top marine predators along the New Zealand coast, but now they are opportunistic eaters, feeding on fish, marine invertebrates, and even the remains of sea mammals.

articles.title: Climate change poses severe threat to bowhead whale habitat
articles.author: Science Daily
articles.summary: New research shows that sea ice loss due to climate change will cause the bowhead whale's habitat to contract by up to 75 per cent in the Arctic due to warming climate. The research was based on 11,700 years of data from the Arctic Ocean.

articles.title: Trump's tax bill to cost 830,000 jobs and drive up bills and pollution emissions, experts warn
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Bill will unleash millions more tonnes of planet-heating pollution, say experts. It couldn't come at a worse time, they say. It will be bad for the environment, they warn. It's bad for human health, too, as Bill will create more pollution.

articles.title: ‘Unprecedented' marine heatwave hits waters around Devon, Cornwall and Ireland
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: Scientists warn of profound impacts as sea temperatures rise by up to 4C above average for springtime for this time of the year, according to the NOAA.   Â   for this reason, sea temperatures could rise by as much as 4C higher than normal.

articles.title: Sea temperatures around the UK and Ireland soar to 4°C above usual - following an ...
articles.author: The Daily Mail
articles.summary: Waters around the UK and Ireland are gripped by an 'extreme' marine heatwave. The British sea temperatures are currently what would be expected for mid-June, thanks to an exceptionally warm spring and calm winds. The sea temperatures in the UK are currently 4°C (7.2°F) above usual.

articles.title: INSECTICIDE: TIME Cries Climate Change Causing Bug Life to Go Buzz-erk!
articles.author: Joseph Vazquez
articles.summary: TIME reporter Simmone Shah warned on May 20 that climate change is making the summers less buggy for insects. Marc Morano quipped that it's the latest in a series of nonsensical eco-doomism pushed by leftist media this week: CBS News warned pregnant women are in danger due to climate change, and TIME also warned climate change will cause more home foreclosures.

articles.title: Summers Are Getting Warmer Nationwide, Including in Milwaukee
articles.author: Danielle Kaeding
articles.summary: The last two years have been the hottest on record in Wisconsin. 97 percent of 242 cities studied are seeing hotter summers with an average temperature increase of 2.6 degrees Fahrenheit since 1970. Nearly one-third of those cities have warmed by 3 degrees or more. In Milwaukee, the city has warmed 3.4 degrees in the last 55 years, adding about 17 more days that have been hotter than normal.

articles.title: Regional Singers & Songwriters Join In Music To Support Manna Foodbank
articles.summary: The Flood: Music for Manna is available online for song downloads with proceeds going toward Asheville's Manna Foodbank. Manna experienced damages and losses due to Hurricane Helene. Project Producer Guy Smith and artists Jay Brown and Josh Pierce were our guests. This conversation originally aired in May 2025.
